citations.narrative:
The door at the back of the eastern ring-tailed lemur enclosure is in disrepair. The frame of the door is made of metal
tubing and PVC pipe. The bottom left section of the vertical pipe is broken approximately 3 inches from the bottom.
Enclosures that are not structurally sound may allow the animals within to escape or allow other animals to enter the
enclosure. These conditions might also lead to injury of the animals.
Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury,
contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering. To be corrected by June 5, 2024.

A section of the perimeter fence failed to maintain the 3-foot minimum distance from a primary enclosure. Along the
western side of the petting zoo is a newly constructed section of the perimeter fence. This fence section maintained an
average distance of approximately 24 inches from the enclosure but approached as close as 15 inches in some areas.
There was no written approval for this variance from the regulation.
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.
Perimeter fences must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact
between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in
distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. To be corrected by July 3, 2024.

Some of the bird perches were damaged. A perch holding a hyacinth macaw had a central pole approximately 4” X 4” in
diameter. This pole was covered by a layer of clear, hard acrylic or plastic. The bottom section of the plastic like
substance was broken, leaving jagged edges near some of the lower bird perches. There were two other perches
observed with similar damage.
Structures in bird enclosures that are not kept in good repair can lead to harm or injury to the birds.
Interior surfaces and surfaces that come in contact with birds must be free of jagged edges or sharp points that could
injure the birds. To be corrected by June 5, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was no documented program of environmental enhancement for the birds housed at the
facility.
An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of birds.
Dealers. Exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds, it must be in accordance with the currently
accepted professional standards and as directed by the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by June 5, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Darren Rausch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The door at the back of the eastern ring-tailed lemur enclosure is in disrepair. The frame of the door is made of metal 
tubing and PVC pipe. The bottom left section of the vertical pipe is broken approximately 3 inches from the bottom.  
 
Enclosures that are not structurally sound may allow the animals within to escape or allow other animals to enter the 
enclosure. These conditions might also lead to injury of the animals. 
 
Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, 
contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering. To be corrected by June 5, 2024. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A section of the perimeter fence failed to maintain the 3-foot minimum distance from a primary enclosure. Along the 
western side of the petting zoo is a newly constructed section of the perimeter fence. This fence section maintained an 
average distance of approximately 24 inches from the enclosure but approached as close as 15 inches in some areas. 
There was no written approval for this variance from the regulation. 
 
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can 
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. 
 
Perimeter fences must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact 
between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Such fences less than 3 feet in 
distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. To be corrected by July 3, 2024. 
3.150(c)(3) 
   
Facilities, general.

Some of the bird perches were damaged. A perch holding a hyacinth macaw had a central pole approximately 4” X 4” in 
diameter. This pole was covered by a layer of clear, hard acrylic or plastic. The bottom section of the plastic like 
substance was broken, leaving jagged edges near some of the lower bird perches. There were two other perches 
observed with similar damage. 
 
Structures in bird enclosures that are not kept in good repair can lead to harm or injury to the birds. 
 
Interior surfaces and surfaces that come in contact with birds must be free of jagged edges or sharp points that could 
injure the birds. To be corrected by June 5, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, there was no documented program of environmental enhancement for the birds housed at the 
facility. 
 
An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of birds.  
 
Dealers. Exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment 
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds, it must be in accordance with the currently 
accepted professional standards and as directed by the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by June 5, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Darren Rausch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
